body:
Code is here:
https://github.com/fastlane/fastlane/blob/f892ca98af7ee316e563d07a93a54c96c58b6a47/fastlane/lib/fastlane/fast_file.rb#L29-L33

How can one differentiate between third party and standard libraries? 
Is there a definitive list to use for that check?

> How can one differentiate between third party and standard libraries?

You realistically cannot, and should not try to differentiate. There are many ways to confuse any kind of check, like `$LOAD_PATH` modifications which can pre-empt the loading of a RubyGem, or trigger it, depending.

> Is there a definitive list to use for that check?

No. Don't maintain a list of white listed libraries to require. These depend on Ruby version, the OS you're on, the specific configure flags you used to compile Ruby, your Gemfile, etc. (i.e. sometimes rdoc is a stdlib sometimes it's a gem, same for json and more).

IMO you should not warn for normal require usage. The easy fix here is to disable the warning because it provides no value and only confuses users and actually recommends an action that will _break_, not fix, their setup.

If you _really_ need to do this, the only "reliable" way would be to either monkeypatch into [RubyGems' `require` implementation](https://github.com/rubygems/rubygems/blob/a90989f70aa8843d1fac2e35ce83bd8e47cd5328/lib/rubygems/core_ext/kernel_require.rb) or basically reimplement the full lookup semantics for how RubyGems decides whether a path is a gem or just a normal Ruby file. Reliable is in quotes because both of these things will need you to maintain compatibility across RubyGems versions, Ruby version, and it's quite a bit of work and _will_ break over time.

So you really shouldn't.

There hasn't been any activity on this issue recently. Due to the high number of incoming GitHub notifications, we have to clean some of the old issues, as many of them have already been resolved with the latest updates.

Please make sure to update to the latest `fastlane` version and check if that solves the issue. Let us know if that works for you by adding a comment :+1:

Friendly reminder: contributions are always welcome! Check out [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/fastlane/fastlane/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more information on how to help with `fastlane` and feel free to tackle this issue yourself :muscle:
Whose reply do we need for this to move forward?

Any reply keeps this open.
Only a PR can really move this forward.
Would you accept a PR to remove this warning?
Removing the warning doesn't seem like a solution to the actual problem, as this is a useful feature in normal usage of fastlane.

@janpio can you provide information about when this warning is actually useful? I can't think of any case where warning a user about a missing gem is useful. If the gem is actually missing they will get an error instead of the warning, and the error will be more accurate.

But if this is a nonstarter, can you provide some guidance on what type of PR would be accepted to resolve this? I'm all for doing the work if the fastlane team doesn't want to, but if y'all are also setting restrictions on how this is resolved it would be useful to know what those are up front-- again my approach would have be to rip out the false-positive-prone warning, and that seems to be problematic.

This is not about missing gems (afaik), but about using `require ...` to use one in a `Fastfile`. Here is the documentation for `fastlane_require`: https://docs.fastlane.tools/advanced/Fastfile/#using-fastlane_require I don't know all the reasoning behind this feature and how and where it is useful, but I am aware it exists and sets the context where this warning is useful.

Thanks for your interest by the way, I wish I could give you better and more exhaustive answers but I am "only" doing a lot of triage at the moment and can't look to deep into code.

issue.title: [fastlane] attempt to require lib in Fastfile before warning

repository.name: fastlane
repository.description: ðŸš€ The easiest way to automate building and releasing your iOS and Android apps

issue.body:
<!-- Thanks for contributing to _fastlane_! Before you submit your pull request, please make sure to check the following boxes by putting an x in the [ ] (don't: [x ], [ x], do: [x]) -->

### Checklist
- [x] I've run `bundle exec rspec` from the root directory to see all new and existing tests pass
- [x] I've followed the _fastlane_ code style and run `bundle exec rubocop -a` to ensure the code style is valid
- [x] I've read the [Contribution Guidelines](https://github.com/fastlane/fastlane/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [ ] I've updated the documentation if necessary.

### Motivation and Context

See #15211 for issue details

### Description

Prior to warning the user about a missing gem (with installation guide), attempt to require the library. This avoids issues where the library being required is not actually a gem but a local Ruby file or gem provided by Ruby's stdlib.

Tested with RSpec with new tests & fixtures added.

### Testing Steps

1. `bundle exec rspec`

You can also test manually by using something like `require 'base64'` inside of a Fastfile and expecting no warning. You should still see a warning with any gem that is not installed on your system (i.e. anything that will lead to a LoadError).

body: PR opened to resolve this in #15354 without changing any existing behaviors.
